overview.note: Correlation analysis based primarily on Mizrak et al. (2025) quantitative data. Stanton et al. (2016) provided qualitative evidence only. Reeves et al. (2021) was a theoretical review.

primary_finding.interpretation: Weak positive correlation between years of experience and cybersecurity fatigue

experience_fatigue_relationship.context: While the correlation is statistically significant, the small effect size (r=0.15) suggests experience is one of many factors contributing to cybersecurity fatigue, not a primary driver.

fatigue_mental_health.interpretation: Moderate negative correlation - higher fatigue associated with worse mental health

fatigue_productivity.interpretation: Moderate negative correlation - higher fatigue associated with lower productivity

mental_health_productivity.interpretation: Moderate positive correlation - better mental health associated with higher productivity

fatigue_sector.interpretation: Weak positive correlation - certain sectors experience more fatigue
fatigue_sector.note: Healthcare professionals reported highest fatigue levels

fatigue_job_position.interpretation: Weak negative correlation - job position relates to fatigue levels

fatigue_predicts_productivity.interpretation: Cybersecurity fatigue explains 36% of variance in productivity

fatigue_predicts_mental_health.interpretation: Cybersecurity fatigue explains 28% of variance in mental health outcomes

model_fit.interpretation: Excellent model fit - all indices exceed recommended thresholds

fatigue_to_mental_health.interpretation: Strong negative direct effect of fatigue on mental health

fatigue_to_productivity.interpretation: Very strong negative direct effect of fatigue on productivity

support_to_productivity.interpretation: Strong positive effect of mental health support on productivity

fatigue_prevalence.note: First empirical evidence of security fatigue phenomenon

mental_health_resources.finding: Mitigates negative effects of fatigue on productivity

recommendations: Limit security alerts to critical only

synthesis.main_conclusion: Cybersecurity fatigue is a real and measurable phenomenon that negatively impacts both productivity and mental health across multiple sectors
synthesis.experience_role: Years of experience shows a small but significant positive correlation with fatigue (r=0.15), suggesting experienced professionals may face slightly higher fatigue levels, though this is not the primary driver
primary_drivers: Lack of perceived benefit from security behaviors
strongest_relationships: Mental Health Support → Productivity (β=0.62, SEM path coefficient)
synthesis.evidence_quality: High - progression from qualitative discovery (2016) to theoretical framework (2021) to quantitative validation with SEM (2025)
synthesis.practical_implications: Organizations should prioritize simplifying security protocols, implementing digital detox policies, and providing mental health resources to mitigate cybersecurity fatigue

limitations.meta_analysis_not_performed: Raw data from individual studies not available for true meta-analysis
limitations.limited_experience_data: Only one paper (Mizrak et al., 2025) provided quantitative correlation between experience and fatigue
limitations.cross_sectional_design: Correlation does not imply causation; longitudinal studies needed
limitations.sector_coverage: Limited to four sectors (IT, healthcare, finance, education)
limitations.geographic_scope: Studies conducted in US and Turkey only
